quote: Commander's Log.  Stardate 48481.2.     My senior staff and I have been asked    to address the annual Starfleet    Symposium on the current situation    in the Gamma Quadrant.  I'm looking    forward to the opportunity... and to    visiting my sister in Portland.
Entering Earth orbit.
Now there's something I never get    tired of looking at.
If you ask me, the seas could be a    little more purple.
Funny, I was just thinking they    weren't green enough.
I guess it's true what they say.     "There's no place like home."
No matter what color the water is.
Commander, I'm receiving an incoming    emergency message...       It's from DS Nine.
On screen.
Commander... am I glad to see you.
This better be good, Quark.  You're    on an emergency channel.
I just received a message from the    Grand Nagus.  He wanted me to remind    you of the critical role he played    in establishing contact with the    Dominion.
You can assure the Nagus his    assistance will be mentioned    prominently in my report to Starfleet.
There was one more thing, Commander.
It seems the Nagus's nephew Belongo    is currently being held by Starfleet    authorities on Aldebaron Three... a    slight misunderstanding, I'm sure.
A misunderstanding the Nagus no doubt    would like cleared up.       I do owe him a favor.
He thinks so too.  And to quote the    one hundred and eleventh Rule of    Acquisition...

"Treat people in your debt like    family... exploit them."       I've been reading up.       Tell the Nagus that I'll do what I    can, but remind him of the two hundred    and seventeenth Rule of Acquisition.
"You can't free a fish from water"       I'll be sure the Nagus gets the    message.
We'd better get ready, Benjamin.    (off his reaction,     reminding him)   Dinner, tonight.  With Admiral    Drazman.
Not "Droner" Drazman?  The commander    of the Proxima Maintenance Yards?
You're more than welcome to come    along.  The entire senior staff was    invited.

Full dress uniforms... fine table    linens... and a different fork for    every course... thanks but no thanks.     That's why I stayed an enlisted man.     No one expects us to show up for    formal dinners.
Major, Constable, care to join us?
No thanks.
I'd say this is strictly a Starfleet    occasion.
She's all yours, Major.       Energize, Mister O'Brien.
Aye, sir.
That's strange.
What's wrong?
Nothing serious.  Just a power    fluctuation in the annular confinement    beam.       Hold on.  That's impossible.
What happened?
I stabilized the beam... but according    to our sensors they never materialized    at their destination.       They're just... gone.
Look what we have here.
Who are you?
Who am I?       Do you believe this?  Sleeping    Beauty's asking me questions.
Hey Vin, we've been working all    night... why don't we forget these    guys?  I just want to go home and    see Sonya and the kids, and get some    sleep.
What are you, an anarchist?  There's    a law against sleeping in the streets.
Though I do like the matching pajamas.       All right, let's see some logo.
Logo?
I.D.       Identification.  UHC Card?  Transit    pass?
Where are we?  What happened to    Starfleet Headquarters?
(to his partner,     sarcastic)   Perfect.  Just what we need... two    more dims.
Shotguns... those uniforms... There's    something familiar about them.
Yeah, probably from the last time    you were in a Sanctuary District.
Sanctuary District?       What year is this?
Same year it was yesterday... Twenty    twenty-four.    (prods Bashir with     his shotgun)   Let's go.
How do they find us?
Are you okay?
My head...
What happened... Did you get jacked    or something?
Jacked?
You know, robbed?
Did they get your credit chips...    your I.D.?
Looks like they got everything.
Except my brooch.
Where do you live?  Can you get home    okay?
I just got here.  I was traveling    with some friends... we got    separated...
Well you shouldn't be walking around    without I.D.       You'd better order replacements.
You can use my Interface terminal if    you want.  My office is right around    the corner.
That's very kind of you...
Chris.  Chris Brynner.
I'm Jadzia.
Pretty name.  What is it, Dutch?
Something like that.       Thanks for the help.
Don't mention it.  It's not everyday    I get to rescue a damsel in distress.
Check the Heisenberg compensators.     I'll run a level-one diagnostic of    the pattern buffer, see if there's    any kind of field imbalance.
Chief.
Any news from Starfleet?

Nothing good.  As far as they can    tell, Commander Sisko and the others    never materialized in San Francisco.     According to their sensors, our    transporter signal disintegrated    immediately after we began the beam    out sequence.
That doesn't agree with our records.     The system log shows that the    transport was completed successfully.     They definitely materialized    somewhere.
That's good news, anyway.  The    question is... where?
I wish I knew.  Whatever the answer    is, it's not in the log.  The only    thing unusual it recorded was the    variance in the annular confinement    beam...
But you corrected for that..
It was a simple adjustment.  The    beam was just reacting to the    accumulation of chroniton particles    in the ship's hull.
Chroniton particles?
They're emitted by the cloaking    device.  Sometimes they become lodged    in the ship's ablative armor matrix.
But we've used the transporter many    times since the cloaking device was    installed.  There's never been a    problem before.
And I don't know why it would be a    problem now.
Wait a minute.       It looks like there was a surge of    temporal energy a few seconds before    the initiation of the transporter    sequence.
Tell me that's a clue.
It's a clue all right.  I'm just not    sure what it means yet.
How do you feel?
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: Better.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: Me too.  Probably transporter shock.     Disorienting, but it wears off    quickly.       At least I know one thing... we're    definitely in San Francisco.  I caught    a glimpse of the Golden Gate Bridge    a few blocks back.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: I saw it too.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: Any idea what happened to our    combadges?
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: They must've been stolen when we    were unconscious.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: This isn't the Earth we're used to,    Doctor.  That's still at least a    century away.       I wish I knew what happened to Dax.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: She was in the transporter beam with    us.  Whatever affected us must've    affected her too.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: That means she's probably somewhere    nearby.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: As soon as we get a chance, we've    got to find her.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: And then what?
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: And then... we find a way home.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: Okay, let's go.  Hurry it up.       Sonya's gonna kill me.
scene: 14   EXT. SAN FRANCISCO - SANCTUARY DISTRICT GATE -

quote: What is this place?
A Sanctuary District.
I'm afraid twenty-first century    history isn't one of my strong suits.     Too depressing.
It's always been a hobby of mine.     They made some ugly mistakes, but    they also paved the way for a lot of    the things we take for granted.
I assume this was one of the mistakes.
A bad one.  By the early twenty-   twenties there was a place like this    in every major city in the United    States.
But why are these people in here?     Are they criminals?
No.  People with criminal records    weren't allowed in the Sanctuary    Districts.
Then what did they do to deserve    this?
Nothing.  They're just people.  People    without jobs or places to live.
So they get put in here?
Welcome to the twenty-first century.
Shall we?
Sorry to keep you waiting.  Were you    able to order new I.D.?
Just finished.  It took a little    while to convince them I was who I    said I was.
They'll be expressing me a new transit    pass and a couple of credit chips in    a few hours.  I asked them to send    it here.  I hope you don't mind.
No problem.
Thanks... for letting me use your    terminal... and your account.
Glad I could help.       You know... those are really...    unusual.
You mean...       My tattoos?
It's amazing work.  Where'd you get    them done... Japan?
How'd you guess?

I used to have one myself.  A Maori    tribal pattern.  All the way down my    arm.  Got it in high school... back    in the nineties... just like everybody    else.       But I had to have it removed.  You    know how it is.  To get the government    contracts, you have to look just    like the rest of the drones.       I guess that makes me a sell-out.
Not necessarily.  What kind of    business do you do?

You don't know?       I've got to talk to my public    relations people.    (gestures to the     computer)   I'm Chris Brynner... of Brynner    Information Systems.  You know...    Interface Operations... Net Access...    Channel Ninety...
You're that Chris Brynner?
So what do you think?  Am I a sell-   out or not?
Probably.  But I won't hold it against    you.
So, these friends you told me about...    Is there any way you can get a hold    of them?
I wish I could.
Other hand.
Welcome to SafeTech's fingerprint    database.  your government discount    has been accepted.  Remember our new    retinal scan services, now accessible    on Channel One-Seventy-Eight.
Yeah, yeah.  Save the commercials.
We're sorry... but the fingerprints    you have provided are not on record.
No I.D., no fingerprint records, no    Interface account.  It's like you    two don't exist.
Since we don't exist, why not let us    go?
Let's see, you don't have any I.D.,    you don't have any money, and you're    both dressed like clowns.  You figure    it out.

"Please fill out these forms.  Answer    all the questions to the best of    your ability.  If you cannot speak    English an interpreter will be    provided.  If you cannot read, the    questions can be given verbally.  If    there is any part of this form you    do not understand, please ask one of    our staff for assistance."       Now sit down, shut up, and fill out    the forms.  And if you've got any    problems, don't come to me with them.
Tell Admiral Ngomo I appreciate her    offer, but I don't want anyone beaming    onto this ship until we know what's    going on.  If they want to come up    by shuttle, that's fine.
Major.

I think I know what happened to    Commander Sisko and the others.  The    temporal surge we detected was caused    by the explosion of a microscopic    singularity  passing through this    solar system.  Somehow, the energy    emitted by the singularity shifted    the chroniton particles in our hull    into a high state of temporal    polarization.
Which means what?
Which means that the transporter    beam was redirected when it passed    through the polarized particles.
Redirected where?
Not "where."  When.  The beam was    redirected through time, not space.     They arrived in San Francisco, just    like they were supposed to...
But not when they were supposed to.     How much time are we talking about?     Days?  Weeks?
More like centuries.
This is ridiculous.  We've been    waiting here for three hours and the    line's barely moved at all.
I got one word for you pal... plenty    of overtime.
That's three words.
Hey, for a dim, you're pretty smart.     Now get back in line.
(quietly; re: the     Dims)   Commander, these people are mentally    ill.  They need proper medical    treatment.
I know.  But they're not going to    get it.  Not now anyway.
What is it?
That calendar over there... It says    today is August thirtieth, twenty-   twenty-four.
I'm not sure what you...
Ever hear of the Bell Riots?
Vaguely.

It was one of the most violent civil    disturbances in American history.     And it happened right here.  San    Francisco, Sanctuary District "A,"    the first week of September, twenty-   twenty-four.
That's only a few days from now.
Which means if we don't get out of    here soon, we're going to be caught    right in the middle of it.
So just how bad is this riot going    to be, Commander?

Bad.  The Sanctuary residents will    take over the District.  Some of the    guards will be taken hostage.  In    the end, the government will send in    troops to restore order.  Hundreds    of Sanctuary residents will be killed.
Hundreds.       And there's nothing we can do to    prevent it.
Starfleet's temporal displacement    policy may sound good in a classroom.     But to know that hundreds of people    are going to die, and not to be    allowed to even try to save them...
I sympathize, Doctor.  But if it    makes you feel any better, the Riots    will be one of the watershed events    of the twenty-first century.       Gabriel Bell will see to that.
Bell?

The man they named the Riots after.     He was one of the Sanctuary residents    who'll be guarding the hostages.     The government troops will storm    this place, based on rumors that the    hostages have been killed.       But it'll turn out that the hostages    were never harmed.  Because of Gabriel    Bell.  In the end, Bell will sacrifice    his own life to save them.  He'll    become a national hero.  Outrage    over his death, and the death of the    other residents, will change public    opinion about the Sanctuaries.     They'll be torn down and the United    States will finally begin correcting    the social problems it had struggled    with for over a hundred years.
All because of what's going to happen    here in a few days.
Which means if we warn these people    about what's coming, if we try to    help them in any way, we risk altering    a pivotal moment in history.  And we    can't let that happen.
Hey, I hate to break up this intimate    conversation, but you're next.
Is something wrong?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Well, according to these forms, you're    supposed to be dims.  But you're    not, are you?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: I hope you're not disappointed.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Pleasantly surprised is more like    it.       I guess I owe you an apology.  If    I'd known you were gimmies, I could've    processed your application much    sooner.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Gimmies?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: They're American slang terms.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: I try not to use them, but it's a    bad habit.       Gimmies are people like you... people    looking for help... a job, a place    to live.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: And what about the dims... Don't    they need help?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: The dims should be in hospitals.     But the government can't afford to    keep them there, so we get them    instead.       I don't like it, but that's the way    it is.       I see here that you both just arrived    in San Francisco.  Do you have any    jobs lined up?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: No.  We weren't really planning on    being here that long.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Have you got a place to stay?  Or    anyone who can vouch for you?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: We were traveling with a friend...    but we were separated right after we    arrived.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Do you have any way of contacting    this friend of yours?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Not at the moment.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: In that case, I'm afraid you'll have    to stay here in the Sanctuary for    the time being.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: You mean we can't leave?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: It's for your own safety.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Really.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: And it's the law.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: And what about jobs?  How are we    supposed to find work and a place to    stay if we're stuck in here?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: One of the services we provide is    job placement.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: And how long does that usually take?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: I wish I could give you a definite    answer.  But right now jobs are hard    to come by... what with the economy    and all...       My advice is to be patient.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: In the meantime, take these.       They're your ration cards.  You can    use them to get food and water at    any of the distribution points in    the district.  Hang on to them.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: And where are we supposed to stay    while we're here?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Anywhere you like.  The buildings in    the district are there for everyone    to use.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Thanks for all your help.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: One more thing... a little advice.     Stay away from District Security.     They've had their budget cut again.     They're overworked and underpaid...       Just give them a lot of space.       And watch out for ghosts.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Ghosts?
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: That's what we call people who haven't    integrated well into the Sanctuary.     They can be dangerous; they tend to    prey on other residents.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Thanks for the warning.  We'll stay    out of their way.
scene: 28   INT. PROCESSING CENTER - LEE'S CUBICLE - DAY #1

quote: Dax to Sisko... Dax to Bashir... If    you can hear me, please respond...
Okay, my assistant was able to get    you a room at the Clift for the next    five nights.
You didn't have to do that.
I know.  But I wanted to.       So what are your plans?
I still have to find my friends.
Well, I hope you don't mind, but I    had Britt do some checking.  No one    matching their descriptions has been    admitted into any of the City's    hospitals or trauma wards.
That's good news.
Look, I'd like to know how this all    turns out.  I'm having a little get-   together tomorrow, here in the office.     You're welcome to come if you want...    you and your friends.
I'd like that.
Well, good luck.
Thanks.  I could use it.
You can't come in here.
We're just looking for someplace to    sleep.
Look someplace else.
Let me guess.  This building's full.
Sorry.
Every building we go to, it's the    same story.  They can't all be full.

Don't be so sure.  One of the main    complaints against the Sanctuary    Districts was overcrowding.  It got    to the point where they didn't care    how many people were in here.  They    just wanted to keep them out of sight.
And once they were out of sight,    what then?       Look at him.  There's no need for    that man to live like that.  With    the right medication, he could lead    a full and normal life.
Maybe in our time...
Not just in our time.  There were    any number of effective treatments    for schizophrenia, even in this day    and age.  They could cure that man    now... today... if they gave a damn.
It's not that they don't give a damn,    Doctor.  It's that they've given up.     The social problems facing them seem    too enormous to deal with.

That only makes it worse.  Causing    people to suffer because you hate    them is terrible... but causing them    to suffer because you've forgotten    how to care... that's even harder to    understand.
They'll remember.  It'll take    time, and it won't be easy, but    eventually people in this century    will remember how to care.

But it makes you wonder, doesn't it?     Are humans really any different than    Cardassians... or Romulans?  If push    came to shove, if something disastrous    happened to the Federation, and we    got frightened enough, or desperate    enough, how would we react?  Would    we stay true to our ideals... or    would we just end up... here... right    back where we started?
I don't know.  But as a Starfleet    officer, it's my job to make sure we    never have to find out.
Get his food card.
Get his food card.
Remember, Doctor, we can't interfere.
You got a problem?
No problem.
You look upset.       If we've offended you in any way,    please tell us so we can be sure not    to do it again.
Don't worry about us.  We're new    here.
I never would've guessed.  Let me    be the first to welcome you.
Would you like a piece of this?
No thanks.
Gimmies... no sense of fun.
We're just looking for a place to    sleep.
In that case, you better look    somewhere else... newboy.
You heard him.  Let's go.
Enjoy your stay... in a few days    you'll feel right at home.
So in theory, we should be able to    travel into the past by focusing the    transporter beam through the polarized    chroniton particles.

The problem is, we don't know where    in time Sisko and the others are.     I've narrowed it down to a dozen    different possibilities.  But we    only have enough polarized chronitons    to make five or six attempts.

We'll have to take our chances.     Pick the most likely time periods    and send a team down with tricorders    to find them.       The hard part will be finding a couple    of volunteers crazy enough to risk    getting lost in time to do the job.
I think I know some likely candidates.
If we get home, I promise not to    complain about the station's    Cardassian beds ever again.
Where is everybody?
In the food lines, waiting for    breakfast.    (hands Bashir a plate     of scrambled eggs)   It's not much to look at, but it's    better than nothing.
Oh yeah, sorry.  They were out of    utensils.       And napkins.
Why am I not surprised?
When you're done eating, I think we    should try to get up on the roof of    one of these buildings.  I want a    better look at this place.
Do you think there's a way out?
If there is, we'll find it.
Not you two again.  I told you, we    don't have any room.
We're not looking to stay.  All we    want is to go up on the roof and    take a look around.
It doesn't matter what you want.     You can't come in.  We've got to    protect what's ours.
Look, maybe we can make a deal.     Isn't there something we can trade    to get access to your building?
I don't know.  What do you have to    offer?
That's what I thought.  Maybe you    should try another building.
Hey, wait a minute.       Maybe we can make a deal after all.
Well at least now we look like we    belong here.
Yeah, and we smell just as bad as    everyone else.
The stairwell must be around here    somewhere.
Stay away from him.
Whatever you say.  Just put the knife    down.
Step into the light.  So I can see    you.
We're new here.  We're just trying    to get up to the roof... get a better    look at this place.
Believe me, it doesn't look any better    from up there.
Dad...
It's going to be okay...
What happened?
He got beaten up by some ghosts.
My wife went to get help, but there's    only one doctor on duty at the    Processing Center.
Why don't you let me take a look?  I    know a bit about medicine.
Julian...
It can't hurt just to look.

Looks like you were lucky.  No broken    ribs and these cuts are mostly    superficial.  You're going to be    okay.       You're going to need some clean rags    and something to disinfect the wounds.     Alcohol will do.
I think I can get some.
Looks like we made a friend.
Sisko and Bashir emerge from the building.  Webb  follows them out.
You know, the District could use    another doctor.
I don't really practice anymore.
But there are people here who need    you.
I'm sorry.  They'll have to get along    without me.
I know you two are new here, so let    me explain something to you.  You    can forget about getting out of here    any time soon.
This is your home now.  The only    help we're going to get is from each    other.  If we don't start pulling    together, we're finished.
All we want is to be left alone.
My mistake.  I thought you wanted to    get out of here.
We do.
Well the only way that's going to    happen is for us to get organized    and let people on the outside know    what's going on in here.
Do whatever you want.  But leave us    out of it.
If you want to be left alone, that's    fine with me.  But if you want to    help us, and help yourselves, you    know where to find me.
Our sea floor mining project is almost    ready to go into operation.
I hear you just came back from    Christchurch?
Yeah.  Did a little skiing on Mount    Cook.
You're lucky.  We had to cancel our    trip to the Alps this year because    of the student protests in France.
I thought the Neo-Trotskyists were    going to put a stop to that.
They're not having any more luck    that the Gaullists did.
Europe's falling apart.
Well, at least we don't have to worry    about that kind of thing here.
Don't count on it.
You'll have to excuse Jadzia's    cynicism.  She got mugged yesterday.     That kind of thing's bound to give    you a negative impression of the    future.
So who mugged you?  Did you see them?
It doesn't really matter.  I'm just    glad I wasn't hurt.
Whoever it was did a thorough job.     They took everything she had, even    her I.D.
Really?  Everything.
Chris came to my rescue.  He let me    use his computer to get replacement    I.D.
You're lucky the police didn't find    you first.  If they'd caught you on    the street without I.D., you might've    ended up in a Sanctuary District.
I thought they stopped doing that.
Why would they?  It's the only way    to keep those people off the streets.
Excuse us for just a minute.
Is that true?
What?
About taking people without I.D.  to    a Sanctuary District.
Of course... why?
I still haven't found my friends.
And you think they might be in a    Sanctuary District?
It's possible.  If you hadn't found    me, I might've wound up in one.  Can    we check and see if they're inside?
That might take some doing.  Sanctuary    District Records aren't posted on    the Net.       But, maybe I can pull in a few    favors...
And I thought the replimat lines    were bad.  By the time we get dinner,    it'll be time for breakfast.
You'd think before they locked    thousands of people into a twenty    square block area, they'd give some    thought to how they're all supposed    to stay fed.
I'll go see how much longer the line    is.
I'm talking to you, gimmie.
Let me see your food card.
What for?
Because I said so.
Let him go.
(can't believe someone's     standing up to him)   What?
I said, let him go.
Well, when you put it that way...
Leave them alone.
Get his card.
Help him.  He wouldn't have gotten    hurt if it wasn't for us.
Breathe, damn you.  Breathe.
He's gone.
Come on.  We've got to get out of    here.
Doctor.  Let's go.
No sign of the police.
Right now, they're the least of our    worries.       That man... the one who got killed    trying to help us...
That was Gabriel Bell.
All right Chief, let's get over to    the transporter room before we change    our minds.

Too late, Major.  It looks like    Starfleet's changed our minds for    us.       I just got a message from Admiral    Wright of Starfleet Command.     Headquarters thinks our plan's too    risky.  They're afraid that while    we're searching for Sisko and the    others, we might contaminate the    timeline.
Get me Admiral Wright.
I had a feeling you'd say that.
That's odd.
What is it?
I'm not getting any response from    Starfleet.
Is there something wrong with our    communications array?  I was just    speaking to Starfleet Security when    my com-line went dead.
There's nothing wrong on our end.     Everything checks out fine.
It could be interference on the com    channels.  Try a wide band subspace    signal.
Still nothing.       Maybe if I direct it toward one of    the Federation communications    satellites in Earth orbit...
What is it, Chief?
They're not there.  The entire Earth    satellite network... it's gone.
The spacedocks?  The orbital habitats?
All of it.  The Utopia Planitia yards    on Mars, the terraforming stations    on Venus... Starfleet Headquarters.
I can't detect a single sign of    Starfleet activity anywhere in this    sector.
Try a non-Federation frequency.
The only subspace signals I'm    detecting are coming from the vicinity    of Alpha Centauri...       And they're Romulan.
That's impossible.
Do you think Sisko and the others    might've somehow altered the timeline?
They must've.
Then why weren't we affected?

I'm not sure...       Maybe... maybe when it exploded, the    singularity that polarized the    chroniton particles created some    kind of subspace bubble around the    ship... isolated it from the changes    in the timeline.  I'd have to run    tests to be sure.       But one thing's for certain, right    now this ship is all that's left of    Starfleet.
If I could've gotten him to a    hospital, or even if I'd had a medical    kit, I might've been able to save    him.
You did all you could, Doctor.
But it wasn't enough, was it?  A    good man died today... because of    us.       And what about the hostages?  What's    going to happen to them?
Without Bell, there's a good chance    those hostages are going to die.
And if that happens, who knows how    it'll affect the future.
We have to save them.  Whatever it    takes, we have to make sure those    hostages survive.
I thought you didn't want to get    involved.
We changed our minds.

Glad to hear it.  We can use all the    help we can get.       This place is about to explode.     Most of us agreed to live here because    they promised us jobs.  I don't know    about you, but I haven't been on any    job interviews lately.  And neither    has anyone else.  They've forgotten    about us.
So what do we do?

We make them remember.  The day after    tomorrow, we're going to hold a rally    outside the Processing Center.  I    want everyone to be there.  Gimmies,    ghosts... even the dims.  We've got    to remind the people outside that we    haven't done anything wrong... that    we're not criminals... and that we    don't deserve to live like this.
We'll spread the word.

Good.       One more thing.  Tell people when    they come to the rally to bring their    families, their kids, and try to    look their best.  After all, we're    not derelicts.  No matter what they    say about us.
(smiles and rubs his     chin)   I could probably use a shave myself.
Not to mention a bath.
You were right.  Your friends are in    Sanctuary District "A."
When can we get them out?
It might not be that easy.  First    the Sanctuary personnel have to find    them.  There are something like ten    thousand people in there...
Did they say how long it'll take?
They're not sure.  But don't worry.     Your friends are fine.  That's the    whole point of the Sanctuary.  To    give people in trouble food and a    place to stay.
If that's all it's for, then why is    there a wall around it?
Two days... in front of the Processing    Center.  Spread the word.
Please, try and be there.  And tell    everyone you know.
We must've talked to five hundred    people today.
That leaves about nine thousand to    go.
Whoa.  Slow down.  What's going on?
One of the guards got into a fight    with a dim.  Everyone's going crazy.     I've got to find my dad.
Sisko and Bashir struggle to get    through the crowd of people, most of    whom are just trying to get to safety.
scene: 56   EXT. OUTSIDE THE PROCESSING CENTER - NIGHT #3

quote: Come on.  We've got to get you off    the street.
scene: 56   EXT. OUTSIDE THE PROCESSING CENTER - NIGHT #3

quote: Everybody, hands on your heads and    face the wall.
You can't do this.
That's enough.
Look who's here.  Way to show    initiative, Newboy.        Throw him back there with the rest    of our... guests.
Throw him back there with the rest    of our... guests.
What the hell do you think you're    doing?
I think I'm a making a political    statement.  Maybe if we're lucky,    we can even stage a nice photo op.        I hope that meets with your    approval.
I hope that meets with your    approval.
Do as he says.
All right!  I've been waiting a long    time for this.  I know it's going to    be worth it.       Ain't that right, newboy?
The name's Bell.  Gabriel Bell.
